I am a second year student and use an M1 Macbook air, the base model of 8 256. 

Your biggest bottle neck will be storage. The RAM is manageable and enough on MacOS. If you're able to stretch your budget, get the 512 GB variant and not the 256 GB one.

Here are my thoughts: 

1.  Most people install linux and a subject in the higher semesters afaik require you to be on linux. This isn't possible yet with the Apple Silicon Macbooks. Support is improving with the Asahi Linux Project but it's not perfect.
2. You'd be better off getting a windows laptop. It's more freedom and you can install linux on it. Linux is an important part of having fun as a developer. 
3. The battery life on the Air is amazing. _amazing_ I can't emphasise that enough. This is one of the only pros I found on this laptop. 
4. You wouldn't be worried about the screen size a lot. It's actually an advantage if you have a smaller laptop. You'd be moving around a lot in college. Having a light bag is important, which leads me to my next point-
5. Do not buy gaming laptops. They have terrible battery life and often come with compromises in build quality. Prefer having metal builds if your budget allows it. 
6. Do not go overboard on performance, balance other aspects like battery, screen, camera, evenly. Extra emphasis on battery. It's a hassle to be connected to the wall always. Anything with an intel i5 12th gen or above will be sufficient.
7. Finally, try getting Intel EVO certified laptops. They offer great battery life and a superior experience generally. If I could go back in time when I was in my first year, I'd buy the [Acer Swift 3](https://www.amazon.in/Acer-Processor-Keyboard-Fingerprint-SF314-512/dp/B0B1F21WVP?th=1) (look for a better configuration if your budget allows for it, this is just a quick link I found on amazon)

I second that. Dual booting was a terrible experience with many windows laptop. There were few subjects that required Unix based system and eventually all of my roommates assignments I made on my Mac as dual booting was painful. Apart from that portability and battery life of Mac really stood out in classes where there were limited charging ports.
Also all softwares were provided by college or were open source.

This is what I did, even though multi-boot is a pain but itâ€™s a good opportunity for a CSE student to learn more about Unix, Linux and low level details. I think starting in this part is a pain, but as you grow you master it and it becomes a trivial thing. 

Having a windows gives more flexibility in terms of experience (using Linux systems like Ubuntu, Kali etc.. recalling these from my college days). Growing up, the focus is more on experimentation, fast execution of plans and fun as well (install cracked games on windows). 

Not all college provides the licenses, like youâ€™ll need to worry about Microsoft office in Mac, not sure if thereâ€™s a free version of it in Mac. 

As a beginner in CSE, I think it makes sense to go through some pain (reads as hard time understanding low level stuff to be able to perform some task without being a script kiddie) to understand about systems better.
